steps.text: Recognize heat stroke: Body temperature above 103°F, hot red dry skin (no sweating), rapid strong pulse, confusion, slurred speech, unconsciousness. This is life-threatening
Call 911 immediately: State 'heat stroke emergency.' This is a medical emergency - brain damage and death can occur within minutes without treatment
Move to cool environment: Get person to shade, air-conditioned building, or cooled vehicle immediately. Remove from sun and heat source
Remove excess clothing: Take off as much clothing as possible. Remove hats, shoes, socks, outer layers. Expose skin for cooling
Cool rapidly and aggressively: Immerse in cold water if possible (tub, pool, lake). If not, spray with cool water and fan continuously. Pack ice around neck, armpits, groin
Focus on high blood-flow areas: Place ice packs or cold wet cloths on neck, armpits, and groin where blood vessels are close to surface. This cools blood faster
Do NOT give fluids if altered mental status: If person is confused, vomiting, or unconscious, do not give anything by mouth. They may choke
Continue cooling until EMS arrives: Do not stop cooling measures. Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR if person becomes unresponsive and stops breathing

name: Heat Exhaustion
description: Overheating with profuse sweating and weakness

steps.text: Move person to cool area and have them lie down
Remove excess clothing
Cool with wet cloths or fan
Give cool water or sports drink if conscious
Monitor for worsening symptoms
Call 911 if symptoms worsen or don't improve in 30 minutes
Recognize hypothermia: Shivering (may stop in severe cases), confusion, slurred speech, drowsiness, weak pulse, clumsy movements. Core temperature below 95°F is hypothermia
Call 911 immediately: Severe hypothermia is life-threatening. Heart can stop if person is rewarmed too quickly or handled roughly
Move to warm environment: Get person out of cold, wind, and wet conditions. Move gently - rough handling can trigger cardiac arrest in severe hypothermia
Remove wet clothing: Cut off wet clothes if needed. Dry the person gently. Do not rub skin - this can cause cardiac arrhythmias
Insulate from ground: Place blankets, sleeping bag, or dry clothing underneath person. Ground contact causes rapid heat loss
Warm the core first: Wrap in blankets focusing on head, neck, chest, and groin. Use your body heat if no other heat source. Add chemical heat packs wrapped in cloth
Warm beverages if conscious and alert: Give warm (not hot) sweet drinks if person can swallow safely. No alcohol - it increases heat loss
Handle very gently: Do not massage limbs or apply direct heat to arms/legs. Cold blood returning to heart can cause cardiac arrest. Wait for EMS to rewarm
Get person to warm area
Do not rub affected area - this causes more damage
Remove wet clothing and jewelry
Immerse in warm (not hot) water 100-104°F for 20-30 minutes
Apply loose sterile bandages between fingers/toes
Seek medical attention - do not rewarm if refreezing is possible
Call 911 immediately
Move to safe area if lightning continues - it's safe to touch victim
Check for breathing and pulse - begin CPR if needed
Check for and treat burns
Look for entrance and exit wounds
Monitor for cardiac problems
